711505f-a.text:
Commercial Garage Company, an old structure on the south side of
18th Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.
1914.

710323f-a.text:
Nos. 122 to 112 Ninth Ave., at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of West 18th Street, showing a row of frame structures that nearly occupy the entire block front from 18th to 17th Streets and which will be demolished according to the New York Times of May 9, 1938 as a portion of planned site of a modern 6-story apartment house. This will rise on a plot 100 x 130 feet and will include the two 4-story brick houses Nos. 366 and 364 West 18th Street; the side wall of one of these appearing on the extreme left of view No. 1. Views 2 and 3 show portions of this wooden row, some of which have brick fronts. This property has been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to the 364 West 18th Street Corporation for '100,000 through Eugene J. Busher Company, who arranged a building loan of 175,000 for ten years to finance the improvement.
Views 1 & 3: March 12, 1933.
View 2:- March 7, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

711455f-a.text:
East of Ninth Avenue between West 18th and West 19th Streets, north side showing the School adjoining Textile High School, #56, P.S.

Board of Education, N.Y.C.
May 27, 1931.

711456f-a.text:
343 West 18th Street, North side showing foyer of Textile High School.

Board of Education, N.Y.C.
May 27, 1931.

711497f-a.text:
18th Street west from but not including Ninth Avenue. In the right foreground is the Spanish Express, No. 405, with its van in front. No. 417-27 is the Greenwich, an old apartment house, seen at the left centre. The white two-story building beyond the Greenwich is the new Borden offices, built about 1926.
July 16, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
R13S5

711498f-a.text:
West 18th Street, east of the N.E. corner of Ninth Ave. Across excavation for the new Textile High is shown West 19th Street, east of the N.E. corner of Ninth Ave. The rear of Nos. 340-338 West 19th Street, (The Mark Twain Apartments) south side, between Eighth and Ninth Aves., is shown on the right. In the background, may be seen the clock tower of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church.
September 1, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

710325f-a.text:
Ninth Avenue, east side, from 18th to 17th Streets. The row of two and three-story houses in the foreground, 124-112 Ninth Avenue, are frame structures which will still stand in 1934.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York,
Negative No. 176,

710326f-a.text:
Ninth Avenue, east side, at 18th Street. The houses in this picture from No. 112 in the right foreground to No. 128 on the N. E. corner of 18th Street are frame structures which will stand in 1934. McParland's Malt and Hops Store, in the centre, is an interesting product of the rapidly dying prohibition era. Stores such as this, selling ingredients and equipment for home brewing,were legion; but the advent of legal beer on April 7, 1933, was a blow which most of them failed to survive.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 165.

711504f-a.text:
West 18th Street, north side, east from 10th to 9th Avenues. Adjoining the N.E. corner of 10th Avenue are two quaint structures No's 461-3. These are shown to better advantage in View 1. Note that the photographer is viewing across a vacant lot at the S.E. corner of 10th Avenue and does not show 9th Avenue.
June 14, 1938
July 16, 1932
P.L.Sperr

711504f-b.text:
West 18th Street, north side, east from 10th to 9th Avenues. Adjoining the N.E. corner of 10th Avenue are two quaint structures No's 461-3. These are shown to better advantage in View 1. Note that the photographer is viewing across a vacant lot at the S.E. corner of 10th Avenue and does not show 9th Avenue.
June 14, 1938
July 16, 1932
P.L.Sperr

710327f-b.text:
Ninth Avenue, east side, north from W. 18th Street (right, not seen), showing a general view of this west side area with one of its arterial transportation lines. Several new apartment buildings are contemplated which will cause radical changes in its contour; one such seen is at the N.E. corner of W. 20th Street. To the right in No. 1 appears a portion of the huge Textile High School. This property, north of 19th Street, and extending to Eighth Avenue, was formerly the easterly part of the Clement C. Moore holdings and has an interesting history. The reader can find same in various quaint publications.
June 15, 1938.
Views 1,2 and 3
N. L. Sperr

711499f-a.text:
West 18th Street, at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Ninth Avenue (elevated line thereon) showing prominently Textile High extending thru the block to 19th Street. Upon this site formerly stood P.S. 56. The photographer is viewing northeastward from a roof top at the S.W. corner. The clearance at the right is to be improved with a modern 6 story apartment house (see N.Y. Times of May 9, 1938).
June 15 1938.
Views 1 and 2
P. L. Sperr

711500f-a.text:
404-406 West 18th Street, adjoining the S.W. corner of Ninth avenue. The former is a two-story and the latter a three-story frame house.
1932.
